questions.text: The boundaries of triangle of Petit, the site for inferior lumbar hernia are all EXCEPT
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Boundaries of triangle of petit are: Laterally- External oblique Medially-latissimus dorsi Below- Crest of ilium Posterior border of internal oblique muscle forms the lateral boundary of superior lumbar triangle.

choices.text: Omphalocele constitutes a part of the cantrell`s pentalogy
Gastroschisis mostly occurs to the right of the umbilicus
Chances of associated congenital anomalies are more with omphalocele in comparison to gastroschisis
Perioperative fluid requirements are more with omphalocele as compared to gastroschisis

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Gastrochisis and Omphalocoele is not correct
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Because of increased fluid losses the fluid requirements are more in gastrochisis as compared for omphalocoele. i.v fluids are started at the rate of 1.5 times maintenance

questions.text: Hernia occurring through a defect in lacunar ligament is known as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hernia associated with congenital dislocation of hip- Narath’s Hernia containing appendix as a content- Amyand’s Hernia through the aponeurosis of pectineal muscle – Cloquet’s through lacunar ligament-Laugier`s hernia.

choices.text: Presents as Swelling at the edge of rectus sheath
Occurs through spigelian fascia which is the aponeurosis of transverse abdominis
Seen in individuals > 50 years and rarely strangulates

questions.text: The true statement in regard to Spigelian hernia is all Except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The narrow and fibrous neck of these hernias commonly leads to strangulation hence surgery is recommended.

questions.text: For suspected strangulated femoral hernia, the LEAST preferred route for surgery in this condition is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lockwood (Low) approach for femoral hernia is the simplest operation for femoral hernia but suitable only when there is no risk for need of bowel resection. Mc evedy (High) approach is ideal in situations where risk of bowel strangulation is high.

choices.text: Positron emission tomography (PET) scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.text: A patient presents with osteomas of the mandible, multiple lipomas and sebaceous cysts, a history of multiple dental abnormalities,and an apparent fibrotic retroperitoneal mass on CT scan obtained for abdominal pain. The next step in management of this patient is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This is a case of gardener’s syndrome which along with the extra intestinal manifestations associated with FAP. So to look for polyps and to rule out colonic ca , take a biopsy if required therefore,the next best step in the management of this patient would be a Colonoscopy.

questions.text: Most important prognostic factor in CDH is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The most important prognostic factor for Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension.

choices.text: Pulmonary hypoplasia is the most important prognostic factor
Patients usually present with respiratory distress and they should be operated in emergency
Operative repair consists of tension free closure of the defect using prosthetic mesh
Few cases of congenital diaphragmatic hernia can be bilateral

questions.text: Which of the following statements about congenital diaphragmatic hernia is false ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B. Operating these patients in emergency setting further increases the stress and adds more insult which leads to reduced survival so we operate on patients of CDH after 24 to 72 hours once the patient's respiratory distress has been stabilized by endotracheal intubation and low flow ventilatory support. Option A. The most important prognostic factor for Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension. Option C. The role of operation is to achieve the tension free closure of the defect either with or without prosthetic mesh use . Option D. It is true that few cases of CDH can be bilateral.

questions.text: Most common organ to herniate in larry’s hernia is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Larry’s Hernia is also called as retrosternal hernia or Morgagni’s hernia. Most common organ to herniate in this condition is transverse colon.

choices.text: Right sided hernias are more common than left sided hernias
Transverse colon is the most common organ to get herniated
Most of the patients are asymptomatic

questions.text: Which of the following statements about morgagni’s hernia is true ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 90 % of cases occur on right side Transverse colon is the most common viscus to get herniated Most patients are asymptomatic at birth but as soon as the defect is recognised you have to go for a prompt surgical repair to prevent incarceration and strangulation.

questions.text: A patient presented with respiratory distress just after birth. On auscultation you could hear bowel sounds in left chest. The picture of the child has been shown to you . What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In figure you are able to see the scaphoid abdomen. The triad of : Respiratory distress + Scaphoid abdomen and dextrocardia points towards the diagnosis of CDH.

questions.text: Structure not passing through the esophageal hiatus:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) left phrenic nerve pierces left cupola

questions.text: Diaphragm develops from all of the following structures, except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Development of diaphragm 1. Septum transversum →Central tendon 2. Pleuroperitoneal membranes →Small intermediate muscular portion 3. Mesentery of esophagus →Crura 4. Body wall →Peripheral muscular diaphragm Cervical myotomes (muscular input)

questions.text: Which of the following incisions is taken for diaphragmatic surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Diaphragmatic incisions can be divided into three groups: Circumferential, Central tendon, and Radial. 1.Circumferential Incision – Circumferential incisions in the periphery result in little loss of function. – Must be at least 5 cm lateral to the edge of the central tendon to avoid the posterolateral and anterolateral branches of the phrenic nerve. –Difficult to correctly realign after long operation. – Placement of surgical clips on each side of the muscular incision can greatly facilitate the correct spatial orientation on closing. 2.Incisions in the central tendon: – Do not interrupt any major branch of the nerve itself. – Provide excellent visualization of the abdomen from the thorax, and vice versa. – Easy to open and to close. 3.Transverse Radial Incision: – Made from the midaxillary line centrally – Relatively Safe – May result in segmental diaphragmatic paralysis if the incision transects the crural or posterolateral branches of the phrenic nerve.

questions.text: Type IIIA in Nyhus classification of hernia:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Nyhus developed a classification based on the size of the internal ring and the integrity of the posterior wall

questions.text: Type 7 Gilbert hernia is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Gilbert designed a classification for primary and recurrent inguinal hernias done through an anterior approach. It is based on evaluating 3 factors: Presence or absence of a peritoneal sac. Size of the internal ring Integrity of the posterior wall of the canal.

questions.text: Most common type of hernia in females is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Most common hernia in males: Indirect inguinal hernia Femoral hernia is more common in females MC type of hernia in females: Indirect inguinal hernia Direct inguinal hernia is more common in the elderly

questions.text: A 44-year-old male undergoes a laparoscopic mesh repair for hernia. The surgical procedure is uneventful. He returns for follow-up. The wound is clean, dry, and intact. What is the optimal convalescent period required before returning to work for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The optimal time of convalescence after hernia repair is unknown. After traditional open surgery, patients have been asked to convalesce for 6 to 8 weeks. However, after laparoscopic mesh repair, patients may return to strenuous activity in 2 to 3 weeks.

questions.text: Triangle of doom is related to ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The Triangle of Doom is an anatomical triangle defined by the vas deferens medially, spermatic vessels laterally and peritoneal fold inferiorly. This triangle contains external iliac artery and vein, the deep circumflex iliac vein, the genital branch of genitofemoral nerve and hidden by fascia, the femoral nerve. It bears significance in laparoscopic repair of groin hernia. Surgical staples are avoided here No dissection or other activity whatsoever should be performed in this area, as an injury to either of these vessels could be fatal. Moreover the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve lies in this area and is equally in danger in case of careless dissection

questions.text: A 3 year old child comes with the hernia of the hydrocele sac. Management will include ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Treatment of choice of congenital hernia is herniotomy.

questions.text: Most common nerve injured in inguinal hernia repair is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A. Most common nerve injured during a hernia surgery is ilioinguinal nerve Option B. Most common nerve injured in appendicetomy is iliohypogastric nerve. It increases the chances of the occurrence of hernia. Option C. Genitofemoral nerve is the most common nerve injured during psoas hitch procedure.

questions.text: Strangulation most commonly occurs in ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A strangulated hernia occurs when the blood supply to the herniated tissue has been cut off. This strangulated tissue can release toxins and infection into the bloodstream, which could lead to sepsis or death. Strangulated hernias are medical emergencies. Any hernia can become strangulated. Symptoms of a strangulated hernia include pain near a hernia that gets worse very quickly and may be associated with other symptoms Femoral hernia is most commonly associated with strangulation and so whenever we have a femoral hernia we need to operate on that patient . Option B and C. Direct and indirect inguinal hernia have less chance of strangulation. Out of these two more chance of strangulation is present with indirect inguinal hernia.

questions.text: Medial border of Femoral ring is formed by ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Femoral ring :

questions.text: In laugier’s hernia opening is in the ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

choices.text: Below and lateral to pubic tubercle
Above and lateral to pubic tubercle
Above and medial to pubic tubercle
Below and medial to pubic tubercle

questions.text: Neck of sac of femoral hernia lies ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Relation to the pubic tubercle is important in distinguishing a femoral hernia from an inguinal hernia. The neck of the femoral hernia lies below and lateral to the pubic tubercle (position of the femoral ring), whereas the inguinal hernia is above and medial to the pubic tubercle

questions.text: Howship romberg sign is seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Howship–Romberg sign is a sign used to identify obturator hernia. The sign is inner thigh pain on internal rotation of the hip. It can be caused by an obturator hernia.

questions.text: If caecum is involved as a part of the wall of the hernia and not the content it will be known as ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sliding hernia is a type of hernia in which the posterior wall of the sac is the viscus. In this great care must be taken in order to avoid injury to the visceral organ. It occurs in about 3 % of inguinal hernias. Richter’s hernia :Richter's hernia is the protrusion and/or strangulation of part of the intestine's antimesenteric border through a rigid small defect in the abdominal wall. Spigelian hernias, also known as lateral ventral hernias, are a type of abdominal hernia along the semilunar line, resulting in herniation between the muscles of the abdominal wall.

questions.text: Mayo’s operation is done for ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Small umbilical hernias: Closed primarily Defect > 3 cm : Closed with mesh repair Mayo's Operation- It is used for umbilical hernia repair In this,through a transverse elliptical incision sac is identified and dissected . Herniotomy is done. Double breasting of the defect in the rectus sheath is done by interrupted non-absorbable suture.

questions.text: In moor’s classification of omphalocele, type I umbilical defect is less than ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: In retrocolic gastrojejunostomy, hernia occurring through window in transverse mesocolon is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Internal hernias occurring through the window in transverse mesocolon after retrocolic gastrojejunostomy is known as stammer’s hernia. Stammer’s hernia can lead to colonic ischemia.

questions.text: Hernia containing meckel's diverticulum is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Littre's hernia - hernia with Meckels's Diverticulum Option A. Richter's hernia: strangulated hernia involving only one sidewall of the bowel, which can result in bowel perforation through ischaemia without causing bowel obstruction or any of its warning signs. Option B. Pantaloon hernia: a combined direct and indirect hernia, when the hernial sac protrudes on either side of the inferior epigastric vessels Option D. Maydl's hernia -(hernia-in-W) The hernia contains two loops of bowel arranged like a 'W'. The central loop of the 'W' lies free in the abdomen and is strangulated where as the two loops present in the sac are not.

questions.text: Hernia into pouch of douglas is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Berger's hernia - hernia in Pouch of Douglas Option A. Beclard hernia - femoral hernia through saphenous opening Option B. Bochdalek hernia :(congenital posterolateral hernia of the diaphragm) Option C. Barth's hernia :Hernia of the loops of intestine between the serosa of the abdominal wall and that of a persistent vitelline duct.

choices.text: Located below the umbilicus and always in the midline
Located above the umbilicus and always in the midline
Located above the umbilicus and on either sided
Can be seen anywhere on abdomen

questions.text: True about epigastric hernia is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Epigastric Hernia : About 3% to 5% of the population has epigastric hernias. More common in men Located between the xiphoid process and umbilicus Usually within 5 to 6 cm of the umbilicus. Defects are small and often produce pain out of proportion to their size owing to incarcerated preperitoneal fat.

questions.text: Spigelian hernia is a type of hernia occurring at ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A Spigelian hernia (or lateral ventral hernia) is a hernia through the Spigelian fascia, which is the aponeurotic layer between the rectus abdominis muscle medially, and the semilunar line laterally. These are generally interparietal hernias, meaning that they do not lie below the subcutaneous fat but penetrate between the muscles of the abdominal wall; therefore, there is often no notable swelling.

choices.text: Internal hernia occurring behind Roux-en-Y limb
An internal hernia occurring through window in the transverse mesocolon

questions.text: Peterson hernia:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Peterson hernias are internal hernias which occur in the potential space posterior to a gastrojejunostomy. This hernia is caused by the herniation of intestinal loops through the defect between the small bowel limbs, the transverse mesocolon and the retroperitoneum, after any type of gastrojejunostomy. The laparoscopic approach facilitates the occurrence of this type of hernia, due to the lack of post-operative adhesions which prevent bowel motility and hence, herniation. Stammer’s hernia: Internal hernia occurring through window in the transverse mesocolon after retrocolic gastrojejunostomy.

questions.text: In video assisted thoracoscopic surgery for better vision the space in the operative field is created by :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In contrast to laparoscopic surgeries, working space for VATS (video assisted thoracoscopic surgery) is not created by insufflations of gases, rather air is removed from ipsilateral lung so as to collapse the lung. For VATS one lung anaesthesia is used.

questions.text: The Grynfeltt – Lesshaft triangle is bounded by all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The superior lumbar triangle of Grynfeltt – Lesshaft is bounded by the 12th rib superiorly, internal oblique inferiorly and the sacrospinalis medially. Inferior lumbar triangle is bounded by iliac crest, latissmus dorsi and external oblique.

choices.text: Originates from the external iliac artery
Located along the lateral margin of the internal inguinal ring
Anastomoses with the superior epigastric artery
Cremastric artery is a branch of the inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: True about the inferior epigastric artery are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The inferior epigastric artery is located medial to the deep inguinal ring and hence an incision in the deep ring should be made laterally. It arises from the external iliac artery just above the inguinal ligament and anastomoses with the superior epigastric branch of the internal thoracic artery anterior to the posterior layer of the rectus sheath. It gives the cremasteric branch which accompanies the spermatic cord and supplies the cremaster and the coverings of the cord.

choices.text: Defect in the transversus abdominis aponeurosis
Defect always located below the arcuate line
Most hernias appear above the umbilicus

questions.text: True about Spigelian hernia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) They affect men and women equally and can occur at any age, but are most common in elderly people. They arise through a defect in the spigelian fascia, which is the aponeurosis of transversus abdominis. The spigelian fascia extends between the transversus muscle and the lateral border of the rectus sheath from the costal margin to the groin, where it blends into the conjoint tendon. Most spigelian hernias appear below the level of the umbilicus near the edge of the rectus sheath, but they can be found anywhere along the spigelian line. the defect is almost always above the arcuate line. In young patients they usually contain extraperitoneal fat only but in older patients there is often a peritoneal sac and they can become very large indeed. Surgery is recommended because the narrow and fibrous neck predisposes to strangulation

choices.text: Femoral hernia may present in this manner

questions.text: False about the hernia shown below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This is a case of Richter’s hernia where a wall of the bowel herniates through a defect. It may be small and difficult or even impossible to detect clinically. Bowel obstruction may not be present but the bowel wall may still become necrotic and perforate with life-threatening consequences. Femoral hernia may present in this way often with diagnostic delay and high risk to the patient. It presents with features of gastroenteritis rather than constipation.

choices.text: CT scan is investigation of choice for complex incisional hernia
MRI is investigation of choice for sportsman’s groin with pain
X ray abdomen is helpful for diagnosing hiatal and diaphragmatic hernia
USG is helpful for diagnosing content of irreducible hernia

questions.text: False about investigations for hernia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) X ray chest and not X ray abdomen is used for hiatal and diaphragmatic hernia. X ray abdomen is of little values for investigation of hernia.

choices.text: Not all inguinal hernias require surgery
Small neck hernias are more dangerous than large neck hernias
Pain, tenderness and skin colour changes imply high risk of strangulation
Not all femoral hernias need surgery

questions.text: True about principle of management of hernia are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A femoral hernia should always be operated as it has a narrow neck and has a high risk of strangulation. All inguinal hernias do not need surgery. A narrow neck hernia has a high risk of obstruction and strangulation.

choices.text: Mesh should overlap at least 2 cm around the defect
Polyester is a monofilament synthetic mesh

questions.text: True about mesh in hernia repair are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Polyester is a multifilament (braided) synthetic mesh. This structure may allow infection to take hold, aided by its hydrophilic property. However, this property also allows rapid vascular and cellular infiltration within the fibrils, aiding host immune responses to infection and providing a stronger host–tissue interface. PTFE meshes are flat sheets and as a result do not allow any tissue in-growth. They are used as a non-adhesive barrier between tissue layers. A well-placed mesh should have good overlap around all margins of the defect, at least 2 cm but up to 5 cm if possible.

choices.text: On lay mesh is in the subcutaneous plane
Plug mesh is a type of in lay mesh
Sub lay mesh is placed between the fascial layers or immediately extraperitoneally
No mesh can be placed intraperitoneally

questions.text: True about the statements below are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The mesh can be placed: • just outside the muscle in the subcutaneous space (onlay); • within the defect (inlay) – only applies to mesh plugs in small defects; • between fascial layers in the abdominal wall (intraparietal or sublay); • immediately extraperitoneally, against muscle or fascia (also sublay); • intraperitoneally - A recent mesh made entirely of a sheet of condensed PTFE with multiple perforations can be used intraperitoneally because the peritoneum will grow in through its perforations whereas bowel will not adhere to its inside.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department with groin pain. Examination reveals that the patient has an indirect inguinal hernia. Which of the following nerves is compressed by the herniating structure in the inguinal canal to give the patient pain?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The ilioinguinal nerve runs with the spermatic cord to innervate the anterior portion of the scrotum and proximal parts of the genitals and could be compressed during an indirect inguinal hernia. The other nerves listed are not likely to be compressed by the hernia. The iliohypogastric nerve innervates the skin of the suprapubic region. The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve innervates the skin over the lateral thigh. The subcostal nerve innervates the band of skin superior to the iliac crest and inferior to the umbilicus.

choices.text: Roof of the canal is formed by the conjoined tendon
Anterior wall is formed by the external oblique aponeurosis
Superficial inguinal ring is a defect in the external oblique aponeurosis
Deep inguinal ring is a defect in the transversus abdominis muscle

questions.text: True about the statements about inguinal canal are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Deep ring is a defect in the fascia transversalis and not in the transversus abdominis muscle.

choices.text: Superior epigastric artery forms lateral boundary

questions.text: True about boundaries of the Hasselbach’s triangle are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Direct hernia is a result of stretching and weakening of the abdominal wall just medial to the inferior epigastric (IE) vessels. Looked at from within the abdominal cavity, there is a triangle referred to as Hasselbach’s triangle, the three sides of which are the IE vessels laterally, the lateral edge of rectus abdominis medially and the pubic bone below (the iliopubic tract).

questions.text: According the European classification of hernia, a primary, Indirect inguinal hernia with a 3 cm defect would be classified as?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The European Hernia Society has recently suggested a simplified system of classification:- primary or recurrent (P or R); lateral, medial or femoral (L, M or F); defect size in finger breadths assumed to be 1.5 cm. A primary, indirect, inguinal hernia with a 3-cm defect size would be PL2.

questions.text: All are examples of herniorrhaphy except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lichtenstein repair is an example of hernioplasty as a mesh is used for re-enforcing the posterior wall and the deep ring. Rest all techniques are examples of herniorrhaphy where sutures are used only to strengthen the abdominal wall.

choices.text: Obturator hernia is more common in females
Posterolateral perineal hernia enters the ischiorectal fossa
Gluteal hernia passes through the lesser sciatic foramen
Obturator hernia is prone to strangulation

questions.text: All the statements below are true except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Gluteal hernia is herniation of contents throughthe greater sciatic foramen, either above or below the pyriformis. Perineal hernia This type of hernia is very rare and includes:postoperative hernia through a perineal scar, which may occur after excision of the rectum; median sliding perineal hernia, which is a complete prolapse of the rectum; anterolateral perineal hernia, which occurs in women and presents as a swelling of the labium majus;posterolateral perineal hernia, which passes through the levator ani to enter the ischiorectal fossa Obturator hernia, which passes through the obturator canal,occurs six times more frequently in women than in men. The swelling is liable to be overlooked because it is covered by pectineus. It seldom causes a definite swelling in Scarpa’s triangle. These hernias have often undergone strangulation, frequently of the Richter type, by the time of presentation A sciatic hernia passes through the lesser sciatic foramen.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis presents with abdominal pain and a large umbilical hernia. Temperature is 97.8°F, pulse 78 beats/min, blood pressure 105/63 mmHg, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and saturation 98% on room air. Exam shows a large, dull to percussion abdomen with flank fullness, a fluid shift, and a reducible umbilical hernia. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Umbilical hernias are common in patients with ascites, occurring in up to 20% of these patients. They develop as a result of increased intraabdominal pressure, muscle wasting, fascial thinning, and nutritional deficits. Ascites management should be optimized prior to repair in order to decrease intraabdominal pressure and minimize recurrence. Asymptomatic hernias should be observed. Indications for repair include symptoms, leakage of ascitic fluid, incarceration, and strangulation. Spontaneous rupture and massive leakage of ascitic fluid is a surgical emergency due to the risk of peritonitis and death. Unfortunately, the recurrence rate following repair in patients with ascites is as high as 73%.
